text:
We're opening a new channel: <#C037X8XMFB3|reading-together>

This channel will be host to in-depth discussions of FoC-relevant academic papers and other long, substantial, or deep materials that deserve thorough consideration and reflection. It'll also be a place to request these sorts of materials — if you're looking for papers on a specific topic, post a request in this channel and the audience there might be able to help you find some.

Here's how it fits in with our existing channels:

<#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> — Deep, substantial discussions emerging from your own thoughts on the future of programming.
<#C037X8XMFB3|reading-together> — Deep, substantial discussions emerging from FoC-related books or academic papers, and requests for such.
<#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work> — Links to FoC-related materials that you created, with the discussion focused on positive critique and encouraging feedback.
<#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together> — Links to FoC-related materials that you didn't create, shared for general/casual interest.
<#C01932BJGE8|present-company> — All other discussions/links that might be of interest to the community, even if not directly pertinent to the future of programming.

Why are the channels divided in this way? To help _the audience_ find something interesting to read or discuss. Each channel has a different tenor—a different kind of signal/noise—and when they're mixed together they tend to drown each other out. This plurality of channels places a bit of additional burden on those who post — you need to make sure you're posting to a channel that is compatible with what you're posting. When in doubt, just give it your best guess — though you can always DM me to ask, too.

Finally, this seems like a great time to plug the <https://futureofcoding.org/member-handbook|Member Handbook>.

As I always say... _keep it futuristic_ :amiga-tick:
